label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, December 25, 1944
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, lamenting her being in a prison camp during Christmas, describing his failed attempts at making Christmas dinner, and reminiscing on Christmases past that they had spent together. This letter was written to Gertrude when she was a prisoner of war in Europe and was likely to have been received in the package that was given to her upon her escape and return to the continental United States.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Letter 12
December 25, 1944
Mrs Gertrude S. Legendre,
1st. Lt. WAC
U.S. Prisoner of War in Germany,
[at] International Committee of the Red Cross Directory Service,
Geneva
Switzerrland,
Via New York, N.Y
Gertie Darling,
Today is Christmas. How strange it seems as I sit here
to think that you are in a prison camp. E ven a fortune teller could
not foreee these things that come up in ones life. Maybe the one that
lived in Summerville and did not give you a peek at the f[u]tu[r]e saw what was
coming and just took your money but did not think he should let you
know what was going to happen. About the only consolation that I can give
you is that you can be fairly certain that this will probably be the worst
Christmas that you will ever spend. To this I think you will add a strong
"AMEN".
Last night was wonderful. I had two twenty five pound turkies
to dress and cook. I could not leave them for today because like any other
day we are at the office and will only get home a few minutes before our
guests arrive for dinner. First I cleaned then and found all sorts of things
that I did not know turkeis possessed , Then came the making of the stuffing
Loaves of bread were torn apart and divided into little pieces. To this greet
mass of dough I added six cans of oysters, chopped celery, cayenne pepper,
celery salt,milk, some kind of meat sauce and everything else that was in
the kitchen. The entire mixture tas then kneeded and pounded until it
looked really terrible. When this point had been arrived at I fi lled each t
turkey full and sewed than up. Into the ovens they went. One oven I set at
three fifty and the other at two fifty. It was eleven oclock by now so
I fell into bed smelling of turkey and stuffing to the point where I
vowed that I would never est a piece of turkey again in my life. While
this ha[d] been going on Morris had been hanging wre[a]ths and bits of tinsel
on everything. However he has become so met[h]odical th[a]t he does not hang
anyting without measuring to see if it is the same height from the floor as
something else. The result is that though he has been pottering around the
apartment for the past three nights I can not see that there has been
any great change. This morning I bounced out of bed bright and early
and swung open the oven door that had been set at three fifty degrees.
You have never seen such a sight in your life. The turkey had swollen up
to the size of a hippo and all the stuffing had burst out. His legs which I
had tied together had broken in two and the skin was raised up in great
air bubbles like that fish in paper begs that Morris always talks about in
New Orleans. It can safely be said that it was the most terrifying sight
that I h[a]ve ever seen. The entire oven seemed to be full of turkey. Most of
it had exploded over everything but theire were sections that had remained
intact and this I tied together again. The other turkey that had been xet
[End Page 1]
at a lower temperature was a wonderful golden brown and looked delicious.
Guess we just overcooked the explosive one.
Somehow before the guests arrive I have to make a corn pudding
and heat up the green peas. If things follow their usual course I expect th
puddings to swell up to such a size that there will not be room for the
guests in the apartment and it will even run down the steps to meet them
in true christmas style. Personnally I believe everyone would have been
far happier with a lot to drink and a sandwhich rather than this grand
style dinner but the old man says no, this is what they want.
Elmer Lee and his orchestra are going to be there playing soft
music and I expect before the evening is over everyone will be up and
on their feet trying to prove they know how to do those south sea island
dances. There will be s great deal of wiggling and not very much
dancing. As yet I have not attmepted to learn then but after demands
for exhibitions while I was back in the states I think that if my old
bones will hold out I will have to learn a turn and a twist here and
there. 
Just so I would not starve over the season I went to the
club last night and had the most delicius turkey dinner. All white meat
with lots of stuffing and good things. The orchestra was playing
holy night and all the old christns carrols. It was so lovely listening
to the soft music and looking out over the calm sea at the sinking sun.
I felt that I could look across that shinning blue surface and see you
away off in the distance just on the horizon. I felt that you were comming
towards me and somehow for a while you did not seen so far off but were
close and I could see your smile, your brown eyes and the little curls
on your forehead. All the memories of the Christmases we had spent together,
of the laughter and happiness as we opened our presents, the squeeks from
the little rubber mice the dogs had received, Bos delighted crys over
not the presents but the ribbon they were wrapped in, the making of the
eggnogg, and then all the negroescomming for their presents. The little
ones so shinning and clean in their white dresses , the big onles shuffing
their feet and saying happy christmas Missis, happy Christmas Boss. Then
the enormous dinner , the protrnding stomachs, and the sleep on he sofas
afterwards. What fun and happiness that was and how long it has been
since we have known it. However everything must have an ending sometimes,
and I suppose that this war will come to an end somedays. If not by next
christms at least in three or four years  Then we can once more start
doing all the things we like and making plans that would take six
generations of long living people to carry out.
Goodbye darling. I am so sorry that you are going through
this dreadful period and I feel so dreadful that there is nothing
that I can do. You use to say that you could not understand why I could
not do something about your coming out here and now you probably wonder
why I cannot do something about getting you out. Please believe me that
the answer is the same in both cases. This letter brings you all my love
and I can only hope that before very long they will exchange you and that
you will be home again.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
